_link.title: I can draw and label animal and plant cells with their organelles

toLevel2.question: Which organelle is found in animal cells but is typically absent from plant cells?

options.text: Lysosome
options.explanation: Lysosomes are found in animal cells but are typically absent from plant cells. Plant cells use vacuoles for similar digestive functions.

options.text: Nucleus
options.explanation: The nucleus is found in both animal and plant cells.

options.text: Mitochondrion
options.explanation: Mitochondria are found in both animal and plant cells for cellular respiration.

options.text: Ribosome
options.explanation: Ribosomes are found in both animal and plant cells for protein synthesis.

toLevel2.question: Which three structures are found in plant cells but not in animal cells?

options.text: Cell wall, chloroplasts and large central vacuole
options.explanation: Plant cells have a rigid cell wall, chloroplasts for photosynthesis, and a large central vacuole, none of which are found in animal cells.

options.text: Nucleus, mitochondria and plasma membrane
options.explanation: The nucleus, mitochondria, and plasma membrane are found in both plant and animal cells.

options.text: Ribosomes, Golgi apparatus and rough ER
options.explanation: Ribosomes, Golgi apparatus, and rough ER are found in both plant and animal cells.

options.text: Lysosomes, vesicles and smooth ER
options.explanation: Lysosomes are found in animal cells, and vesicles and smooth ER are present in both cell types.

toLevel2.question: Which organelles are shared by both animal and plant cells?

options.text: Nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, rough ER, smooth ER, Golgi apparatus and vesicles
options.explanation: Both cell types share these organelles. The differences are that plant cells additionally have a cell wall, chloroplasts, and large central vacuole.

options.text: Only the nucleus and plasma membrane are shared between the two cell types
options.explanation: Many more organelles are shared, including mitochondria, ribosomes, rough and smooth ER, Golgi apparatus, and vesicles.

options.text: Chloroplasts, cell wall and large central vacuole are found in both cell types
options.explanation: These three structures are exclusive to plant cells and are not found in animal cells.

options.text: Lysosomes and chloroplasts are the only organelles found in both cell types
options.explanation: Lysosomes are typically in animal cells only, and chloroplasts are in plant cells only.

toLevel2.question: In a plant cell drawing, how should the cell wall be shown relative to the plasma membrane?

options.text: As a rigid outer layer surrounding the plasma membrane
options.explanation: The cell wall is located outside the plasma membrane and should be drawn as a rigid outer boundary.

options.text: As a layer inside the plasma membrane, closer to the nucleus
options.explanation: The cell wall is external to the plasma membrane, not internal.

options.text: As a replacement for the plasma membrane in plant cells
options.explanation: Plant cells have both a cell wall and a plasma membrane; the wall does not replace the membrane.

options.text: As a thin dotted line identical to the plasma membrane
options.explanation: The cell wall should be drawn as a rigid, thicker structure distinct from the flexible plasma membrane.

toLevel2.question: How should the vacuole be drawn in a plant cell diagram?

options.text: As a large central structure taking up most of the cell interior
options.explanation: The large central vacuole in plant cells occupies most of the cell's interior and should be drawn accordingly.

options.text: As several small scattered structures around the cytoplasm
options.explanation: Small scattered vacuoles are characteristic of animal cells. Plant cells have one large central vacuole.

options.text: As a structure surrounding the nucleus on the outside
options.explanation: The vacuole is a distinct, large central organelle and does not surround the nucleus.

options.text: As a tiny dot near the plasma membrane of the cell
options.explanation: The plant cell vacuole is large, not tiny, and occupies most of the cell interior.

toLevel2.question: Both animal and plant cells contain mitochondria.
toLevel2.explanation: Mitochondria are found in both animal and plant cells, where they carry out cellular respiration to produce ATP.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: Animal cells have a cell wall surrounding the plasma membrane.
toLevel2.explanation: Animal cells do not have a cell wall. Only plant cells have a rigid cell wall outside the plasma membrane.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: Plant cells have a {{blank:1}}, chloroplasts and a large central vacuole, which are not found in {{blank:2}} cells.
A complete animal cell drawing includes the nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, rough and smooth ER, Golgi apparatus, vesicles and {{blank:1}}, plus the {{blank:2}}.
In a plant cell diagram, the {{blank:1}} should be drawn as a rigid outer layer and the vacuole should be drawn as a {{blank:2}} central structure.

toLevel3.question: Why do plant cells need both chloroplasts and mitochondria?

options.text: Chloroplasts produce glucose through photosynthesis and mitochondria break it down to release ATP
options.explanation: Chloroplasts convert light energy into glucose, but the cell still needs mitochondria to break down glucose through cellular respiration to produce usable ATP energy.

options.text: Chloroplasts and mitochondria perform the same function and are interchangeable in plant cells
options.explanation: They perform different functions: chloroplasts carry out photosynthesis and mitochondria carry out cellular respiration.

options.text: Mitochondria produce glucose and chloroplasts break it down for energy inside plant cells only
options.explanation: This reverses the functions: chloroplasts produce glucose through photosynthesis and mitochondria break it down through respiration.

options.text: Plant cells only use chloroplasts during the day and only use mitochondria during the night cycle
options.explanation: Plant cells use mitochondria continuously for respiration, not only at night. Photosynthesis in chloroplasts requires light.

toLevel3.question: Explain why animal cells have lysosomes while plant cells typically do not.

options.text: Animal cells use lysosomes for intracellular digestion, while plant cells use the vacuole for similar functions
options.explanation: Lysosomes contain digestive enzymes for breaking down materials in animal cells. Plant cells use the large central vacuole, which can also contain digestive enzymes, for similar purposes.

options.text: Plant cells do not need to break down any materials because they produce all needed substances
options.explanation: Plant cells do break down materials, but they use the vacuole rather than lysosomes for this function.

options.text: Lysosomes are found equally in both cell types but are simply labelled differently in plants
options.explanation: Lysosomes are distinct organelles typically found in animal cells. Plant cells use vacuoles for similar functions.

options.text: Animal cells have lysosomes only because they consume food while plants never take in nutrients
options.explanation: While diet differs, the reason is that plant cells use vacuoles for intracellular digestion rather than lysosomes.

toLevel3.question: What is the function of the Golgi apparatus in both animal and plant cells?

options.text: It modifies, packages and sorts proteins and lipids for transport within or outside the cell
options.explanation: The Golgi apparatus processes proteins and lipids received from the ER, packages them into vesicles, and directs them to their destinations.

options.text: It produces ATP through cellular respiration in both animal and plant cells equally
options.explanation: ATP production occurs in mitochondria, not in the Golgi apparatus.

options.text: It stores water and minerals to maintain turgor pressure in both cell types
options.explanation: Water and mineral storage for turgor pressure is a function of the vacuole in plant cells, not the Golgi apparatus.

options.text: It synthesises DNA for cell division in both animal and plant cells during growth
options.explanation: DNA synthesis occurs in the nucleus during replication, not in the Golgi apparatus.

toLevel3.question: Why is the plasma membrane still necessary in plant cells even though they have a cell wall?

options.text: The plasma membrane controls what enters and leaves the cell, while the cell wall provides structural support
options.explanation: The cell wall is freely permeable and provides rigidity, but the plasma membrane is semi-permeable and selectively controls substance movement in and out of the cell.

options.text: The plasma membrane replaces the cell wall when the plant cell is actively dividing during growth
options.explanation: Both the plasma membrane and cell wall are present during cell division; neither replaces the other.

options.text: The plasma membrane and cell wall perform identical functions and are completely interchangeable structures
options.explanation: They have different functions: the membrane controls selective transport, while the wall provides structural support.

options.text: The plasma membrane is not actually necessary in plant cells and is simply a remnant of evolution
options.explanation: The plasma membrane is essential in all cells for controlling the passage of substances and maintaining the internal environment.

toLevel3.question: Describe the role of vesicles in both animal and plant cells.

options.text: They transport materials between organelles and to the plasma membrane for secretion
options.explanation: Vesicles are small membrane-bound sacs that shuttle materials between organelles such as the ER, Golgi apparatus, and plasma membrane.

options.text: They provide structural support to both animal and plant cells like a cytoskeleton
options.explanation: Vesicles transport materials; structural support is provided by the cytoskeleton and, in plant cells, the cell wall.

options.text: They produce energy by breaking down glucose through cellular respiration reactions
options.explanation: Energy production occurs in mitochondria. Vesicles are involved in transport and packaging, not energy production.

options.text: They store genetic material as a backup copy in case the nucleus is damaged or lost
options.explanation: Vesicles transport materials between organelles; they do not store genetic material.

toLevel3.question: How do the functions of rough ER and smooth ER differ in a cell?

options.text: Rough ER synthesises proteins using its ribosomes while smooth ER synthesises lipids
options.explanation: Rough ER has ribosomes on its surface for protein synthesis, while smooth ER lacks ribosomes and is involved in lipid synthesis and other functions.

options.text: Both types of ER perform identical functions and differ only in their visual appearance
options.explanation: They have different functions: rough ER synthesises proteins and smooth ER synthesises lipids.

options.text: Smooth ER synthesises proteins while rough ER synthesises lipids for the plasma membrane
options.explanation: This reverses the functions: rough ER (with ribosomes) synthesises proteins and smooth ER synthesises lipids.

options.text: Rough ER is found only in plant cells while smooth ER is found only in animal cells
options.explanation: Both rough and smooth ER are found in both plant and animal cells.

toLevel3.question: Plant cells contain both chloroplasts for photosynthesis and mitochondria for cellular respiration.
toLevel3.explanation: Plant cells need chloroplasts to produce glucose through photosynthesis and mitochondria to break down that glucose through cellular respiration to produce ATP.

options.text: True
False

toLevel3.question: The {{blank:1}} modifies and packages proteins into {{blank:2}} for transport to their destinations.
Rough ER has {{blank:1}} on its surface for protein synthesis, while smooth ER lacks them and synthesises {{blank:2}}.
The plasma membrane is {{blank:1}} and controls substance movement, while the cell wall is freely permeable and provides {{blank:2}} support.

toLevel4.question: A student draws a plant cell with lysosomes instead of a large central vacuole. What correction should be made?

options.text: Replace lysosomes with a large central vacuole, as lysosomes are typically found in animal cells
options.explanation: Plant cells typically lack lysosomes and instead have a large central vacuole that can perform some similar functions. The drawing should show a vacuole.

options.text: The drawing is correct because plant cells contain both lysosomes and a large central vacuole
options.explanation: Plant cells typically do not contain lysosomes; the large central vacuole serves similar digestive functions.

options.text: Add lysosomes to the animal cell drawing instead, as neither cell type actually contains them
options.explanation: Animal cells do contain lysosomes; the issue is that they should not be included in a plant cell drawing.

options.text: The lysosomes should be relabelled as chloroplasts because they have the same shape in diagrams
options.explanation: Lysosomes and chloroplasts are completely different organelles with different structures and functions.

toLevel4.question: A cell diagram shows a nucleus, mitochondria, rough ER, Golgi apparatus, and a plasma membrane but no cell wall, chloroplasts, or large vacuole. What type of cell is this?

options.text: Animal cell
options.explanation: The presence of standard organelles without a cell wall, chloroplasts, or large central vacuole identifies this as an animal cell.

options.text: Plant cell
options.explanation: A plant cell would have a cell wall, chloroplasts, and a large central vacuole in addition to the listed organelles.

options.text: Prokaryotic cell
options.explanation: A prokaryotic cell would lack membrane-bound organelles such as a nucleus, mitochondria, and ER.

options.text: Bacterial cell
options.explanation: Bacterial cells are prokaryotic and do not contain membrane-bound organelles like a nucleus or mitochondria.

toLevel4.question: Predict what would happen to a plant cell if its chloroplasts were removed but it was supplied with glucose.

options.text: The cell could survive because mitochondria can use the supplied glucose for cellular respiration
options.explanation: Without chloroplasts, the cell cannot photosynthesise, but if glucose is provided externally, mitochondria can still break it down to produce ATP.

options.text: The cell would immediately die because chloroplasts are essential for all cellular functions
options.explanation: Chloroplasts are needed for photosynthesis, but the cell can survive on externally supplied glucose using mitochondria for respiration.

options.text: The cell would function normally because chloroplasts have no important role in plant cell biology
options.explanation: Chloroplasts are important for photosynthesis, but the cell can survive without them if glucose is provided externally.

options.text: The cell would convert into an animal cell because it no longer has chloroplasts for photosynthesis
options.explanation: Losing chloroplasts does not convert a plant cell into an animal cell; it would still have a cell wall and other plant-specific features.

toLevel4.question: Compare the organelle composition of a root cell and a leaf cell. Which organelle would be absent from the root cell?

options.text: Chloroplasts, because root cells are underground and do not photosynthesise
options.explanation: Root cells do not receive light, so they typically lack chloroplasts. They still have mitochondria, a nucleus, and other organelles.

options.text: Mitochondria, because root cells do not need energy from cellular respiration
options.explanation: Root cells require ATP from cellular respiration and do contain mitochondria.

options.text: Nucleus, because root cells are simpler and do not need genetic material to function
options.explanation: Root cells are eukaryotic and contain a nucleus with genetic material.

options.text: Cell wall, because only leaf cells require rigid structural support from a cell wall
options.explanation: Both root and leaf cells are plant cells and have cell walls for structural support.

toLevel4.question: A student draws an animal cell with a cell wall. What biological consequence would this incorrectly depicted structure have?

options.text: The cell would be unable to change shape freely, which is needed for functions like phagocytosis
options.explanation: A rigid cell wall would prevent the flexible shape changes that animal cells rely on for processes like phagocytosis, movement, and cell division.

options.text: There would be no consequence because a cell wall would benefit animal cells by providing extra protection
options.explanation: A rigid cell wall would restrict animal cell flexibility, preventing essential functions like shape changes and phagocytosis.

options.text: The cell would immediately die because cell walls are toxic to animal cell plasma membranes
options.explanation: Cell walls are not toxic; the issue is that rigidity would prevent the shape flexibility animal cells require.

options.text: The drawing is actually correct because some animal cells do have cell walls in certain tissues
options.explanation: Animal cells do not have cell walls. Their plasma membrane allows the flexibility needed for their functions.

toLevel4.question: Apply your knowledge to explain why a complete plant cell diagram requires more labelled structures than an animal cell diagram.

options.text: Plant cells have all the organelles animal cells have, plus a cell wall, chloroplasts and large central vacuole
options.explanation: Plant cells contain the same organelles as animal cells (except lysosomes) plus three additional structures, requiring more labels.

options.text: Plant cells have fewer organelles than animal cells, so fewer labels are actually needed in diagrams
options.explanation: Plant cells have more structures overall because they include all common organelles plus cell wall, chloroplasts, and large central vacuole.

options.text: Both cell types require exactly the same number of labels because they contain identical organelles
options.explanation: Plant cells have additional structures (cell wall, chloroplasts, large central vacuole) that require extra labels.

options.text: Animal cells require more labels because they contain lysosomes, which are larger than any plant organelle
options.explanation: While animal cells have lysosomes, plant cells have more total structures to label overall.

toLevel4.question: A student forgets to include vesicles in their animal cell diagram. Why is this an important omission?

options.text: Vesicles are essential for transporting materials between organelles like the ER and Golgi apparatus
options.explanation: Vesicles shuttle materials between organelles and to the plasma membrane. Without them, the diagram fails to show how materials are transported within the cell.

options.text: Vesicles are not important and their omission makes no difference to the accuracy of the diagram
options.explanation: Vesicles play a crucial role in intracellular transport and should be included in a complete cell diagram.

options.text: Vesicles are only found in plant cells so their omission from an animal cell diagram is correct
options.explanation: Vesicles are found in both animal and plant cells and should be included in both diagrams.

options.text: Vesicles are the same as lysosomes, so including lysosomes already covers their function in diagrams
options.explanation: Vesicles and lysosomes are distinct organelles with different functions. Vesicles transport materials while lysosomes contain digestive enzymes.

toLevel4.question: A root cell would lack {{blank:1}} because it is underground and does not receive {{blank:2}} for photosynthesis.
Animal cells lack a cell wall, which allows them to {{blank:1}} shape for functions such as {{blank:2}}.
Plant cells contain all organelles found in animal cells except {{blank:1}}, plus they have a cell wall, chloroplasts and a large central {{blank:2}}.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the claim: 'Plant cells are more complex than animal cells because they have more types of organelles.'

options.text: This is partially true because plant cells have additional structures, but complexity also depends on the functions performed
options.explanation: Plant cells do have additional structures (cell wall, chloroplasts, large vacuole), but animal cells have lysosomes and perform complex functions like phagocytosis. Complexity depends on more than just the number of organelle types.

options.text: This is completely true because having more organelles always means greater cellular complexity
options.explanation: Complexity is not determined solely by organelle count. Animal cells perform complex functions like movement and phagocytosis that require flexibility.

options.text: This is completely false because animal cells have more organelles than plant cells in every case
options.explanation: Plant cells do have more types of structures overall (cell wall, chloroplasts, large vacuole), though animal cells have lysosomes.

options.text: This cannot be evaluated because plant and animal cells have never been compared scientifically before
options.explanation: Plant and animal cells have been extensively compared, and their organelle compositions are well documented.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why understanding the differences between plant and animal cell structure is essential for explaining how organisms function differently.

options.text: Structural differences like chloroplasts and cell walls explain why plants photosynthesise and maintain rigidity while animals cannot
options.explanation: The unique structures in plant cells (chloroplasts for photosynthesis, cell wall and vacuole for rigidity) explain fundamental differences in how plants and animals obtain energy and maintain structure.

options.text: There are no significant functional differences between plants and animals at the cellular level at all
options.explanation: There are major functional differences, including photosynthesis in plants and the flexibility of animal cells, which stem from structural differences.

options.text: The differences only matter for scientists and have no relevance to everyday understanding of biology
options.explanation: Understanding cellular differences explains observable phenomena like why plants wilt, why animals move, and how organisms obtain energy.

options.text: Plant and animal cells are structurally identical so their different functions must be controlled by external factors only
options.explanation: Plant and animal cells have distinct structural differences that directly determine their different functions.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that since plant cells have chloroplasts, they do not need mitochondria. Evaluate this reasoning.

options.text: This is incorrect because chloroplasts produce glucose but mitochondria are still needed to convert it to ATP
options.explanation: Chloroplasts capture light energy to produce glucose, but cells need mitochondria to break down glucose through cellular respiration to produce the ATP needed for cellular processes.

options.text: This is correct because chloroplasts produce all the energy a plant cell needs at all times of day
options.explanation: Chloroplasts produce glucose during photosynthesis, but cells need mitochondria to produce ATP, especially at night when photosynthesis cannot occur.

options.text: This is correct because mitochondria and chloroplasts perform the same function interchangeably in cells
options.explanation: Chloroplasts and mitochondria perform different metabolic processes: photosynthesis and cellular respiration, respectively.

options.text: This is incorrect because mitochondria produce glucose and chloroplasts break it down for energy use
options.explanation: This reverses the actual roles: chloroplasts produce glucose through photosynthesis and mitochondria break it down through respiration.

toLevel5.question: Compare the functional significance of the cell wall in plant cells with the flexible plasma membrane in animal cells. What advantage does each provide?

options.text: The cell wall provides rigid structural support while the flexible membrane allows animal cells to change shape for movement and ingestion
options.explanation: The rigid cell wall supports plant structure through turgor pressure, while animal cells benefit from membrane flexibility for processes like phagocytosis, amoeboid movement, and cell division.

options.text: Both structures provide identical advantages to their respective cell types with no functional differences
options.explanation: The cell wall and flexible plasma membrane provide fundamentally different advantages suited to the different lifestyles of plants and animals.

options.text: The cell wall is a disadvantage for plants because it prevents growth, while the plasma membrane allows unlimited growth
options.explanation: Plant cells can grow despite having a cell wall, and neither structure allows unlimited growth.

options.text: Animal cells would function better with a cell wall, and the lack of one is an evolutionary disadvantage
options.explanation: The absence of a cell wall is advantageous for animal cells because it allows the flexibility needed for movement, phagocytosis, and shape changes.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why a cell that has a nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplasts, a cell wall, and a large central vacuole but no rough ER or Golgi apparatus would struggle to function.

options.text: Without rough ER and Golgi, the cell cannot synthesise, modify, or transport proteins needed for cellular functions
options.explanation: The rough ER synthesises proteins and the Golgi apparatus modifies and packages them. Without these, the cell cannot produce the proteins needed for enzymes, membrane components, and other essential functions.

options.text: The cell would function normally because rough ER and Golgi apparatus are not essential organelles
options.explanation: Rough ER and Golgi apparatus are essential for protein synthesis, modification, and transport, which are critical for cell function.

options.text: The cell would only lose the ability to photosynthesise because the Golgi is needed for chloroplast function
options.explanation: The Golgi apparatus is not specifically needed for chloroplast function; its absence would affect protein processing throughout the entire cell.

options.text: The chloroplasts could compensate for the missing ER and Golgi by producing proteins independently of them
options.explanation: While chloroplasts have some protein synthesis capacity, they cannot replace the comprehensive protein processing functions of the ER and Golgi.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the importance of including all organelles when drawing cells for exam responses. What is lost when organelles are omitted?

options.text: Omitting organelles fails to show functional relationships and suggests incomplete understanding of cell biology
options.explanation: Each organelle performs a specific function. Omitting any organelle from a diagram suggests the student may not understand the complete set of functions the cell performs.

options.text: Omitting organelles has no impact on exam marks because only the cell shape and membrane need to be shown
options.explanation: Accurate labelling of organelles is essential in cell biology diagrams and is typically assessed in exams.

options.text: Only the nucleus needs to be included because it controls all other organelles and represents the whole cell
options.explanation: While the nucleus is important, all organelles have distinct functions that should be represented in a complete cell diagram.

options.text: Omitting organelles improves the diagram because it makes the drawing cleaner and easier to understand
options.explanation: A complete diagram with all organelles demonstrates thorough understanding, which is what examiners assess.

toLevel5.question: Compare how the endomembrane system (ER, Golgi, vesicles) functions as an integrated network in both plant and animal cells.

options.text: In both cell types, the ER produces materials, the Golgi modifies them, and vesicles deliver them to their destinations
options.explanation: The endomembrane system works as a connected network in both cell types: the ER synthesises proteins and lipids, the Golgi processes and packages them, and vesicles transport them to their final locations.

options.text: The endomembrane system only functions in animal cells and is completely inactive in plant cells
options.explanation: The endomembrane system functions in both plant and animal cells, performing protein and lipid processing in both.

options.text: Each component of the endomembrane system works independently with no connection between them at all
options.explanation: The ER, Golgi, and vesicles are connected and work as an integrated system for producing, modifying, and transporting materials.

options.text: The endomembrane system only produces lipids and has no role in protein processing in either cell type
options.explanation: The endomembrane system processes both proteins (via rough ER and Golgi) and lipids (via smooth ER).

toLevel5.question: A biologist discovers a cell with a cell wall, chloroplasts, mitochondria, and a large central vacuole but no nucleus. Evaluate whether this cell is a plant cell.

options.text: It could be a mature plant cell that has lost its nucleus, such as a phloem sieve tube element
options.explanation: Some specialised plant cells, like mature phloem sieve tube elements, lose their nucleus at maturity but retain other organelles. The combination of plant-specific structures supports this identification.

options.text: It cannot be a plant cell because all plant cells must have a nucleus at all times without exception
options.explanation: Some specialised plant cells lose their nucleus during differentiation, such as mature sieve tube elements.

options.text: It must be a prokaryotic cell because the absence of a nucleus is the defining feature of prokaryotes
options.explanation: Prokaryotes lack all membrane-bound organelles. This cell has chloroplasts, mitochondria, and a vacuole, indicating it is eukaryotic.

options.text: It is an animal cell that has acquired plant organelles through a laboratory experiment or mutation
options.explanation: Animal cells do not naturally acquire cell walls, chloroplasts, or large central vacuoles. The structures indicate a plant cell.

toLevel5.question: The endomembrane system connects the {{blank:1}}, Golgi apparatus and vesicles to process and transport {{blank:2}} within the cell.
The rigid cell wall supports plant structure through {{blank:1}} pressure, while animal cells rely on membrane {{blank:2}} for functions like movement.
